newsitem.title: USA: Calif. still opposed to Prudential settlement.
newsitem.headline: Calif. still opposed to Prudential settlement.

text.p: California's Department of Insurance said it still opposes Prudential Insurance Co of America's proposed class-action settlement of consumer sales complaints.
A department spokeswoman declined to comment on whether the state was in talks with Prudential about a possible settlement.

California was one of four states that opposed Prudential's proposed class-action settlement. Two of the other states, Florida and Texas, said Thursday they reached agreements to settle with Prudential.
Massachusetts, which also has opposed the Prudential class-action settlement, declined immediate comment.
"There's nothing new from our office at this point," a California insurance department spokeswoman said.
Last month, California insurance commissioner Chuck Quackenbush said his department had issued subpoenas as part of a stepped up investigation of Prudential's practices.
In addition, he said he was seeking to suspend Prudential's license in the state if the company did not fairly and adequately compensate hundreds of thousands of policyholders.
Under the proposed class-action settlement, Prudential agreed to pay at least $410 million to as many as 10.7 million policyholders who bought permanent life insurance between 1982 and 1985.
That class-action agreement reached in September had improved the terms of an earlier settlement Prudential reached with a multi-state task force of insurance regulators.
Insurance regulators from 43 states and Washington D.C. last summer recommended a $35 million fine and a restitution program for sales abuses by Prudential.
Prudential later reached settlements with the various holdout states.
Just last week, Prudential agreed to pay $384,200 to settle a lawsuit brought by Virginia and acknowledged that some policyholders may have been misled by Prudential agents.
Florida earlier Thursday said it reached a multi-million dollar agreement in principle to settle the deceptive sales practice charges against Prudential.
And Texas said it also had reached a settlement.
The agreements lessen considerably the opposition Prudential will face Monday at a hearing in U.S. district court to determine the fairness of its proposed class-action settlement.
In December, Florida, California, Masschusetts and Texas had urged district judge Alfred Wolin to reject the class-action settlement, calling it unfair to consumers.
